} ,"description": "What is black salve, also known as drawing salve? Learn about its origins and problems surrounding its use."
,"articleBody": "<h3>Definition:</h3><p>Black salve, also known as drawing salve, is a corrosive herbal paste that&#39;s applied to the skin over tumors, skin tags, moles and infections. It has also been applied on the skin over internal tumor sites to “draw out” the cancer.</p><p>Black salve was created by Native Americans to &#34;draw out&#34; infections from the body. The original black salve included the herb bloodroot (Sanguinaria canadensis) and crushed ash, however, there are now many variations on the original recipe. Other common ingredients include chaparral (<em>Larrea tridentata</em>), <a href="https://www.verywell.com/sulfur-what-should-i-know-about-it-89517" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">DMSO</a> (dimethyl sulfoxide), <a href="https://www.verywell.com/chickweed-what-should-i-know-about-it-89437" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">chickweed</a> (<em>Stellaria media</em>), Indian tobacco (Lobelia inflata), comfrey (Symphytum officinale), myrrh (Commiphora myrrha), <a href="https://www.verywell.com/the-benefits-of-althaea-89403" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="3">marshmallow</a> (<em>Althaea officinalis</em>), <a href="https://www.verywell.com/the-benefits-of-mullein-89575" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="4">mullein</a> (<em>Verbascum thapsus</em>), zinc, and Sodom&#39;s apple (Solanum sodomaeum).</p><h3>Can Black Salves Treat Cancer?</h3><p>Although black salves are widely available on the Internet, there is no scientific evidence showing that it&#39;s safe or effective. There is also no evidence that it can &#34;draw out&#34; cancer cells or infection. Possible side effects of using black salve include incomplete removal of the tumor, severe scarring, and the destruction of surrounding tissue.</p><p>In fact, black salves have been tested and found to be completely useless in treating cancer -- and problematic in treating benign moles and skin tags. In addition, the FDA has specifically listed black salve as a <a href="http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/EnforcementActivitiesbyFDA/ucm171057.htm" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="externalLink" data-ordinal="5">&#34;fake cancer cure.</a>&#34;</p><p><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4132006/" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="externalLink" data-ordinal="6">A 2014 published study</a> entitled &#34;Application of black salve to a thin melanoma that subsequently progressed to metastatic melanoma: a case study&#34; follows the story of a woman who used black salve to treat a melanoma (after refusing typical excision with wide margins). Not surprisingly, the treatment was unsuccessful and the woman wound up with deep scars and metastatic organ cancers.</p><h3>Can Black Salves Treat Moles and Skin Tags?</h3><p>Black salves are caustic, meaning that they burn away skin. This may suggest that they would be helpful in removing benign skin features such as moles and skin tags; in fact, however, the salve is likely to do considerably more harm than good.</p><p>Because the compounding of black salves is not regulated, it is impossible to know the potency of the preparation before you apply it. As a result, the preparation may be extremely caustic, meaning that it may burn surrounding tissue. The tissue may become infected; at the very least it will leave a large and unsightly scar.</p><p>While typical removal of moles and scars does involve cutting away a small amount of skin, the procedure is sterile and <a href="https://www.verywell.com/local-anesthesia-defined-3157110" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="7">local anesthesia</a> is used to minimize pain. Black salves, however, are very painful to the skin -- particularly when used on skin that is already inflamed.</p><p>You can <a href="https://www.verywell.com/tips-for-using-supplements-safely-89587" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="8">get tips on using supplements</a>, but if you&#39;re considering the use of black salve, talk with your primary care provider first. Also keep in mind that the safety of supplements in pregnant women, nursing mothers, children, and those with medical conditions or who are taking medications has not been established. Self-treating any condition and avoiding or delaying standard care may have serious consequences.</p><p><sub>Also Known As: drawing salve, black ointment, eschariotics</sub></p><p><sub>Sources:</sub></p><p><sub>Sivyer, G. Application of black salve to a thin melanoma that subsequently progressed to metastatic melanoma: a case study. Dermatol Pract Concept. 2014 Jul; 4(3): 77–80.</sub></p><p><em>Disclaimer: The information contained on this site is intended for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for advice, diagnosis or treatment by a licensed physician. It is not meant to cover all possible precautions, drug interactions, circumstances or adverse effects. You should seek prompt medical care for any health issues and consult your doctor before using alternative medicine or making a change to your regimen.</em></p>"

		<div id="flex_1-0" class="comp flex article-content expert-content">
            <h3>Definition:</h3><p>Black salve, also known as drawing salve, is a corrosive herbal paste that's applied to the skin over tumors, skin tags, moles and infections. It has also been applied on the skin over internal tumor sites to “draw out” the cancer.</p><p>Black salve was created by Native Americans to "draw out" infections from the body. The original black salve included the herb bloodroot (Sanguinaria canadensis) and crushed ash, however, there are now many variations on the original recipe.</p>
	




		<div id="billboard1-sticky_1-0" class="comp billboard1-sticky billboard-sticky" data-height="1050">
    <div class="spacer">
	




		<div id="billboard1_1-0" class="comp billboard1 mntl-gpt-adunit gpt billboard ">
	<div id="billboard" class="wrapper"></div>
		</div>
    </div>
		</div>
            <p class="cb-split"> Other common ingredients include chaparral (<em>Larrea tridentata</em>), <a href="https://www.verywell.com/sulfur-what-should-i-know-about-it-89517" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">DMSO</a> (dimethyl sulfoxide), <a href="https://www.verywell.com/chickweed-what-should-i-know-about-it-89437" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">chickweed</a> (<em>Stellaria media</em>), Indian tobacco (Lobelia inflata), comfrey (Symphytum officinale), myrrh (Commiphora myrrha), <a href="https://www.verywell.com/the-benefits-of-althaea-89403" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="3">marshmallow</a> (<em>Althaea officinalis</em>), <a href="https://www.verywell.com/the-benefits-of-mullein-89575" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="4">mullein</a> (<em>Verbascum thapsus</em>), zinc, and Sodom's apple (Solanum sodomaeum).</p><h3>Can Black Salves Treat Cancer?</h3><p>Although black salves are widely available on the Internet, there is no scientific evidence showing that it's safe or effective. There is also no evidence that it can "draw out" cancer cells or infection. Possible side effects of using black salve include incomplete removal of the tumor, severe scarring, and the destruction of surrounding tissue.</p><p>In fact, black salves have been tested and found to be completely useless in treating cancer -- and problematic in treating benign moles and skin tags. In addition, the FDA has specifically listed black salve as a <a href="http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/EnforcementActivitiesbyFDA/ucm171057.htm" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="externalLink" data-ordinal="5">"fake cancer cure.</a></p>
	




		<div id="native-placeholder_1-0" class="comp native-placeholder mntl-block">
		</div>
            <p class="cb-split">"</p><p><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4132006/" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="externalLink" data-ordinal="6">A 2014 published study</a> entitled "Application of black salve to a thin melanoma that subsequently progressed to metastatic melanoma: a case study" follows the story of a woman who used black salve to treat a melanoma (after refusing typical excision with wide margins). Not surprisingly, the treatment was unsuccessful and the woman wound up with deep scars and metastatic organ cancers.</p>
	




		<div id="billboard2-sticky_1-0" class="comp billboard2-sticky billboard-sticky" data-height="600" data-parent="">
    <div class="spacer">
	




		<div id="billboard2-dynamic_1-0" class="comp billboard2-dynamic mntl-gpt-dynamic-adunit mntl-gpt-adunit gpt billboard dynamic">
	<div id="billboard2" class="wrapper" data-type="billboard" data-pos="btf1" data-priority="3" data-sizes="[[300, 250], [300, 600], [300, 601], [300, 251], [2, 1]]"></div>
		</div>
    </div>
		</div>
            <h3>Can Black Salves Treat Moles and Skin Tags?</h3><p>Black salves are caustic, meaning that they burn away skin. This may suggest that they would be helpful in removing benign skin features such as moles and skin tags; in fact, however, the salve is likely to do considerably more harm than good.</p><p>Because the compounding of black salves is not regulated, it is impossible to know the potency of the preparation before you apply it. As a result, the preparation may be extremely caustic, meaning that it may burn surrounding tissue. The tissue may become infected; at the very least it will leave a large and unsightly scar.</p><p>While typical removal of moles and scars does involve cutting away a small amount of skin, the procedure is sterile and <a href="https://www.verywell.com/local-anesthesia-defined-3157110" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="7">local anesthesia</a> is used to minimize pain. Black salves, however, are very painful to the skin -- particularly when used on skin that is already inflamed.</p><p>You can <a href="https://www.verywell.com/tips-for-using-supplements-safely-89587" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="8">get tips on using supplements</a>, but if you're considering the use of black salve, talk with your primary care provider first.</p>
	




		<div id="billboard3-sticky_1-0" class="comp billboard3-sticky billboard-sticky" data-height="600" data-parent="">
    <div class="spacer">
	




		<div id="billboard3-dynamic_1-0" class="comp billboard3-dynamic mntl-gpt-dynamic-adunit mntl-gpt-adunit gpt billboard dynamic">
	<div id="billboard3" class="wrapper" data-type="billboard" data-pos="btf2" data-priority="5" data-sizes="[[300, 250], [300, 252], [3, 1]]"></div>
		</div>
    </div>
		</div>
            <p class="cb-split"> Also keep in mind that the safety of supplements in pregnant women, nursing mothers, children, and those with medical conditions or who are taking medications has not been established. Self-treating any condition and avoiding or delaying standard care may have serious consequences.</p><p><sub>Also Known As: drawing salve, black ointment, eschariotics</sub></p><p><sub>Sources:</sub></p><p><sub>Sivyer, G. Application of black salve to a thin melanoma that subsequently progressed to metastatic melanoma: a case study. Dermatol Pract Concept. 2014 Jul; 4(3): 77–80.</sub></p><p><em>Disclaimer: The information contained on this site is intended for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for advice, diagnosis or treatment by a licensed physician. It is not meant to cover all possible precautions, drug interactions, circumstances or adverse effects. You should seek prompt medical care for any health issues and consult your doctor before using alternative medicine or making a change to your regimen.</em></p>
